keyTakeAways: Christopher Moynihan, a former Capitol rioter, was pardoned by President Donald Trump in 2021 as part of a blanket pardon of over 1,500 individuals involved in the Jan. 6 attack.
Moynihan was arrested in October 2025 for allegedly threatening to kill U.S. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries via text messages.
The text messages include statements such as 'I will kill him for the future' and 'Even if I am hated he must be eliminated,' indicating a clear intent to carry out violence.
Moynihan was previously sentenced in 2023 to 21 months in prison and 36 months of supervised release, and received a full pardon along with thousands of others.
This arrest highlights concerns raised by law enforcement and lawmakers about the long-term consequences of blanket pardons for individuals convicted of violent acts during the Capitol riot.
Capitol Police have reported a significant increase in threat assessments—projecting 14,000 cases by year-end 2025—indicating a broader pattern of threats to elected officials.
The case underscores tensions between executive pardoning power and public safety, especially concerning individuals with prior criminal histories.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Christopher Moynihan, a man pardoned by President Donald Trump in 2021 after participating in the January 6 Capitol riot, has been arrested for allegedly threatening to kill U.S. House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries via text messages. The threats, including statements like 'I will kill him for the future' and 'Even if I am hated he must be eliminated,' were reported in court documents and led to his arrest by the New York State Police, with assistance from the FBI. Moynihan, who was previously sentenced in 2023 to 21 months in prison and 36 months of supervised release, now faces a felony charge of making a terroristic threat. The arrest comes amid rising concerns about the long-term impact of blanket pardons for Capitol rioters, with Capitol Police reporting a surge in threat assessments—14,000 cases projected by year-end 2025. This case underscores a broader debate over the balance between executive clemency and public safety.
